content.title: Carotid Patch Selection
content.description: Considerations for selecting patch material during carotid endarterectomy closure to reduce restenosis and perioperative complications.
content.definition: Patch angioplasty during CEA involves closing the arteriotomy with a patch to widen the artery and reduce restenosis risk. Options include autologous vein, bovine pericardium, Dacron, and PTFE. Patch closure is superior to primary closure for reducing restenosis and perioperative stroke.

patch_materials: Autologous vein: Saphenous or jugular vein
evidence_for_patching: Patch closure reduces restenosis vs primary closure
Standard of care for conventional CEA
material_comparison: Vein: No infection risk, may aneurysm, variable quality
Bovine pericardium: Easy handling, low infection, no aneurysm
Dacron: Readily available, higher handling stiffness
PTFE: Low thrombogenicity, may have higher infection risk

clinical_pearls: Patch closure is superior to primary closure - use a patch
Bovine pericardium is most commonly used currently
Vein patch may dilate over time - rare pseudoaneurysm
Eversion CEA eliminates need for patch
No single patch material is clearly superior - surgeon preference
